<warlord@...> writes:

> Jim Gilbert wrote:
>> If someone knows more about this or other habaki lore, please let us know.

> Well, not so much lore, but "just another thought".  One of the great
> things I have admired in Nihonto is that even the apparently
> decorative always has a practical purpose.  The taper on a habaki
> performs the same function in the saya as does the taper on a car's
> rear axle and hub.  It "locks", requiring some force to break the
> "union" of the two parts.  The "cat scratches/rain" roughen the
> surface which would allow more "bite" - hence locking force - of a
> habaki in the saya mouth.

Now that you mention it, I'm sure that the scratches also allow each
line of metal then to work with a bit of spring force. As individual
structural units, they can compress or bend slightly, which would not be
possible with the whole. 

This is also something I really like about the whole field of Japanese
swords. Everything is functional.

- darcy
